captions.text: This feature is pure entertainment and we're not trying to make any kind of statement
Hi, it's a nice evening here in Shibuya, Tokyo.
This is a very busy entertainment area of Tokyo.
We're gonna talk to some strangers today, and ask them some questions
About Poland [Kris is from Poland - translator's note]
Let's find out if Japanese people know about Poland.
If they know a lot, we'll hand out prizes in the form of Koleś, a Polish soda.
What comes to mind when you think "Poland"?
A lot of tragic historical events.
The Germans attacked from one side, Russians from the other.
Why do you know that, do you learn it in school?
I learned it in school to get into the University.
I know Poland! I saw their volleyball team
Polish volleyball players are very beautiful!
Do you know any Polish food?
Do you know any famous Polish people?
Do you know any famous Polish people?
And I'm not famous, that's another point.
Everyone's importing vodka, but I forgot the name.
Spirytus, good! You can buy it in Don Quijote right?
You can buy Spirytus in stores in Japan but it's like 95% alcohol.
Do you know where Poland is?
-Here? -No, but it's close, and it's a big country.
Do you know which flag is Polish?
Do you know? Oh good job!
- This is not Poland, I know it. -Yeah, that's Ireland.
You know which flag is Polish? This? Yeah!
There's 10 cities, 3 of them are Polish, the rest is not. Can you guess which ones can be Polish?
Did you say Warszawa? And Poznań?
What's the name of Polish money?
Euro, Złoty, Peso, Yen, Dollar, Crown, Kuna?
It's part of the European Union but we don't use Euro.
There is a word kuna in Polish, it means a small animal, kinda like a squirrel.
I'm gonna ask you to repeat some Polish words, can you repeat some?
This phrase means there's this lazy guy sitting on a couch all day and he does nothing.
Quit nodding you head, you have no idea what he's talking about!
It means Polish type of Gyoza. [dumplings]
Kotlet schabowy z mizerią. [pork cutlet with cucumber salad]
Schabowy z kapustą. [pork cutlet with cabbage]
Means "whatcha gonna do, you can't do anything"
A to feler, westchnął seler [a kid's poem about vegetables]
Thank you very much, good job!
These type of drinks were popular in the 70s and 80s and it's kind of like a comeback.
And that's how we tested the familiarity with Poland among completely random pedestrians in the center of Tokyo.
Some knew more, some knew less.
But from my own experience here in Japan, I have to say a surprising amount of people correlate interesting facts about Poland.
A lot of people associate Lech Wałęsa, Pope John Paul II.
Surprisingly, the name Andrzej Wajda is dropped a lot.
We treated Japanese pedestrians that helped us out to a new beverage called Koleś.
If you would like to check out, you can find the link in the description and floating somewhere around me.
It's a type of old-school orangeade which, as of recently, you can also order through the internet.
And, of course, I welcome you to view upcoming episodes from Tokyo. Cheers!

Boże japończycy w tym wywiadzie są strasznie denerwujący. Aaa jakie to 
trudne? Cały czas coś mówią i to jest denerwujące nic tylko eeee jakieś 
słowa i głupij śmiech. A japonki są takie sztuczne, tam chyba nie ma takich 
które się nie malują. W Polsce też się malują mocno ale nie każda. Raczej 
większość to ma delikatny makijaż przynajmniej ja znam same takie 
dziewczyny. Japonki normalnie wyglądają na takie puste i naiwne, a to jak 
się zachowują w tym wywiadzie tylko to potwierdza. Nie przepadam za ich 
kulturą, ludzie stamtąd są dziwni. .. jedyne co lubię to ich muzykę, 
przeważnie rock i k-pop ale z powerem . O co trudno bo ich pop jest 
przeważnie strasznie cichy i wolny i nie wiem jak im się nie nudzi 
praktycznie w kółko to samo. ﻿
